text:
We're in a similar boat (lots of content quickly) and have recently started building out more of a process around this.

We're using an internal site built on Papyrs that houses all our Sales Enablement content for our campaigns. For every campaign, we have a dedicated page which includes a brief about the project, links to the landing page, campaign emails, a call prompter guide for our Sales team, and any other content that was included, like e-books, infographics, webinar recordings, transcripts, etc...

We're also organizing an internal Box account so we have a central repository for all our marketing assets.

I imagine you could replicate this kind of thing by having project folders which include a central document with links to the campaign materials. The trick is to actually get your sales team to use it as a reference.

We've found having one central internal site that people can visit increases the likelihood that Sales will utilize all the content (versus having multiple documents they need to search for/find)

text:
We have our library in airtable with different tags, views, and tabs to filter down to what you need.

It’s still (and always will be) a work-in-progress) and very manual, except for a zap triggered by new blog posts. Our growth engineer built a simple content lookup bot for slack that runs based on the data in the airtable.

text: Anyone responsible for a regular/recurring newsletter for B2B or work with someone who is? Curious how you measure success.

elements.text: Anyone responsible for a regular/recurring newsletter for B2B or work with someone who is? Curious how you measure success.

text:
For sales, we use an enablement tool called Showpad. We don’t add every piece of content to it, but those that can be most valuable for different audiences, verticals, etc. 

For marketing, honestly, I tell people to do a site search (site:<http://oururl.com|oururl.com> keywords) to find what they’re looking for. :see_no_evil: Otherwise, everyone has access to our CMS library to find hosted items as well as externally published content. Our content calendar is also visible to all of sales and marketing and includes past content, but we use it more for planning ahead than reviewing existing assets.

text: What specific questions do you all ask your sales and/or customer success teams to get the most helpful input for developing content ideas?

text:
I’ve used Guru in the past, but it’s definitely more useful for sales talk tracks and objection handling than creating a true content library.

Like <@UJ2MPBP7V>, we use Airtable so folks can easily filter by persona, topic, publish date, etc. It requires some manual work, but overall I find it to be pretty efficient (and inexpensive!).

elements.text:

Like
, we use Airtable so folks can easily filter by persona, topic, publish date, etc. It requires some manual work, but overall I find it to be pretty efficient (and inexpensive!).

text:
I used to manage a weekly newsletter for a young, growth-stage startup with a decent sized email list. Because the goal was to drive awareness and engagement, the KPIs I cared about most were list size, open rate, and click rate. I focused on building the list as quickly as possible without decreasing engagement metrics.

Now I manage a weekly newsletter for an even smaller, newer startup. In this role, I’m measured largely on top-of-funnel metrics like traffic, so naturally, I wanted to use the newsletter to drive folks back to our site. But I’m finding that this hasn’t been a very useful measure of success because our list is so small. As of this month, I’m focused more on our blog conversion rate and getting more high-quality leads to opt in.

elements.text:
I used to manage a weekly newsletter for a young, growth-stage startup with a decent sized email list. Because the goal was to drive awareness and engagement, the KPIs I cared about most were list size, open rate, and click rate. I focused on building the list as quickly as possible without decreasing engagement metrics.

Now I manage a weekly newsletter for an even smaller, newer startup. In this role, I’m measured largely on top-of-funnel metrics like traffic, so naturally, I wanted to use the newsletter to drive folks back to our site. But I’m finding that this hasn’t been a very useful measure of success because our list is so small. As of this month, I’m focused more on our blog conversion rate and getting more high-quality leads to opt in.

text: Thanks for sharing Shauna! Did the newsletter signups connect with downfunnel goals at all?

elements.text: Thanks for sharing Shauna! Did the newsletter signups connect with downfunnel goals at all?

text:
Not specifically, no. We did track it as a touchpoint in our multitouch attribution model, so we could track its impact on revenue - but that was more informational than anything.

Because we were a small company, our primary goal of the newsletter was driving awareness in our industry among not just prospects, but also analysts, other vendors, etc. So down-funnel goals were less important for that particular channel.

text: I’ve found that asking is putting too much of the onus on those teams to “translate” what customers say into insights you can use to produce content. I suggest instead sitting in on customer calls/meetings or watching chorus recordings (if your company uses that service!). Instead, use CSMs and sales to validate ideas you already have. (“I just wrote this thing about onboarding, do you think our users will find this useful?” etc.)

text:
<@UL1D307FB> Glad it's helpful! Our team is very campaign-focused, and I've found that it helps Sales focus on the specific messaging to use when talking to leads. Plus, promoting content through various campaigns helps helps track performance through the sales funnel.

Granted, not everything is attached to a campaign. So in those cases, we have more product-focused pages on the site which include sales messaging and related content that the reps can use.

elements.text:
Glad it's helpful! Our team is very campaign-focused, and I've found that it helps Sales focus on the specific messaging to use when talking to leads. Plus, promoting content through various campaigns helps helps track performance through the sales funnel.

Granted, not everything is attached to a campaign. So in those cases, we have more product-focused pages on the site which include sales messaging and related content that the reps can use.

text:
I agree w/ <@UJE5LQ2JC> on listening before asking, but I've found questions like these typically yield interesting answers: *Questions for prospects or customers* 
• What is the specific “today” problem they’re trying to solve? 
• What business unit or team are they on? What’s their job title? 
• What other products are they looking at? 
• What are they complaining about? 
• How much explanation do you have to do on finer points? What do prospects/customers struggle to understand? 
• What made us/makes us stand out from competition? 
• What product did they use before us? 
• If they don’t buy our solution, what will they do about their problem? (Sometimes the biggest competitor is not another product, but “no solution” aka complacency).

on listening before asking, but I've found questions like these typically yield interesting answers:

What are they complaining about?
How much explanation do you have to do on finer points? What do prospects/customers struggle to understand?
What made us/makes us stand out from competition?
What product did they use before us?
If they don’t buy our solution, what will they do about their problem? (Sometimes the biggest competitor is not another product, but “no solution” aka complacency).

text:
Hey <@UJ2MPBP7V>! I work with the email list at Groove. The most important success metric we have is something we call “email-assisted trial signups.”

Strategically, it’s “Are people from our email list becoming users of our product?”

I can slice and dice the data in lots of other ways too. Email > Trial > Paying customer. Percentages, etc.

But I’ve found that if we just watch Email list > trial signup, that tells us what we need to know.

I’m sure I’d do it differently with different types of businesses, but that’s what works for us. :slightly_smiling_face:

Every week I also look at new subscribers, unsubscribes and (less importantly) open and click rates.

Strategically, it’s “Are people from our email list becoming users of our product?”

I can slice and dice the data in lots of other ways too. Email > Trial > Paying customer. Percentages, etc.

But I’ve found that if we just watch Email list > trial signup, that tells us what we need to know.

I’m sure I’d do it differently with different types of businesses, but that’s what works for us.
Every week I also look at new subscribers, unsubscribes and (less importantly) open and click rates.
